ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom online
Asynchronous activity (discussion post and reading)

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned reading and writing chinese
Improved Mandarin speaking and Chinese character recognitions skills
Chinese grammar structures, vocabulary, and increased general comfortability with the language.
I learned how to speak Chinese much more fluently and confidently. I improved my writing and reading skills and expanded the variety of characters that I could recognize and identify.
Learnt Chinese, spoken and written.

I definitely improved my listening and speaking skills in Chinese. The professor put a lot of emphasis on making sure our intonations were correct for the quiz recordings and in-class reading exercises.

Unlike other heritage students, I had more difficulty with speaking rather than writing/reading because I dont speak Mandarin at home and actually formally learned it as a child (just forgot much of it due to lack of use), so I found the class relatively laidback.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Too much sporadic irregular work, if it was more systematic it would be nice.
Great instructor and easy to follow class structure

As someone who doesn't intuitively understand the grammar structures, I sincerely appreciated my instructor going over new content (grammar structures) in-class with her slides. Additionally, the consistent synchronous meetings helped facilitate a good learning environment, particularly for language learning. I think the pace of the course could be further refined.

The teaching format is generally helpful; however, I think there could be more variety in the format of presentation. I enjoyed when we did more interactive and culture-based activities, such as briefly presenting on different provinces of China and their features.
Great course! Probably would want less varied assignments  early in the semester it was difficult to remember all the little different things to do.

I loved the small class size, which was a breath of fresh air from all my lectures. It was actually the highlight of my remote semester as I was able to talk to my professor and classmates. I didnt realize how much I missed that until I was at home, staring at a bunch of names on a screen. 

I also appreciated Chen LaoShis feedback on all the recordings and essays. She definitely pointed out the intonations and pinyins I needed to work on.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Homework due on a more scheduled basis rather than spread out.
Synchronous meetings were particularly successful. Additionally, my instructor held consistent and helpful office hours.

Because our class was scheduled to meet every day of the week, we had one day to work asynchronously. Since I definitely felt Zoom fatigue, especially towards the end of the day, as this class was, this was very helpful.
All good!

I liked the engagement during class with students. I dont think the breakout rooms worked very well in the beginning because the students werent very well acquainted with each other and others like me, felt inadequate in our speaking fluency. 

I think at the midpoint of the semester, conversations between peers couldve then been encouraged. I also wished there was more group work involved (i.e. making a skit, play, etc. based on a prompt to present to class) rather than individual essays/projects.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you want to learn Chinese this is a must.
Yes - my Mandarin greatly improved from this course!
Yes, its a fine course, but consider carefully whether you belong in the Heritage track or not.

I think this is a great course to take if you have some basic Chinese skills already. The quizzes and presentations are all regular and scheduled, so you can plan ahead well. I had a great time with Chen laoshi and she very evidently cared about our individual progress.
Yes! Chinese is cool :)

Yes, definitely if youre looking to improve your Mandarin fluency and especially if you plan to travel to a Chinese-speaking country. This would definitely help you in youre thinking about pursuing a business career as well.
